channel.title: TI84 Programming - Exams
channel.description:
Hi lol,
Is programming simple calculation programs (ie, quadratic formula, logs, etc) on a TI84 on final examinations allowed?
I showed my friend a few simple programs and then he was like. CHEATER GTFO.
Yet if they did not want to allow the use of programs on the exams they wouldn't let us use calculators in the first place.
So they clear all memory beforehand. That sucks for everyone.. except the programmers (and the people with photographic memory and can remember complex commands on the calculator and how to remake them in two minutes).
I'm taking Algebra II this year, and then IB Math SL for the next two years.
I have yet to ask my teachers about this since I don't remember a rule about "no programming your own programs", only "your memory will be reset beforehand, so don't even try". They give us the formulas anyway. But what is the policy in your school? What's the general consensus on this?

item.title: TI84 Programming - Exams
item.dc:creator: @Togasa Togasa
item.description:
@Togasa wrote:

Ruby:

In Scotland we’re expected to show all our working so there’s no point.

You can also make the program show you exactly what to write out on a test or HW or whatever…just saying if you were really that lazy.

Read full topic

item.description:
@Togasa wrote:

m1lkman:

I’m forced to clear my calculator’s memory before any math test here in virginia

There;s plenty of easy ways to make sure you still keep certain programs.

item.title: TI84 Programming - Exams
item.dc:creator: @m.dog311 m.dog311
item.description:
@m.dog311 wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:3, topic:439960”]Well I don’t know anything about the American school system but in tea-drinking country they say: “Your graphical calculators will be reset as you enter the exam”, but in reality it never happens. The thing is, there’s no point whatsoever because you are expected to show all your working on the exam anyway to gain marks, so if you “cheat”, you’re just cheating yourself out of the marks which is just plain retarded.

What are you even finding so difficult that requires you to use a program anyway. The only actual “special” functions I use on my calculator is sketching graphs and recursion/iterative things. Mainly its just basic functions and operators stuck together.[/quote]
My TI-84 has saved my ass in Statistics…

Read full topic

item.title: TI84 Programming - Exams
item.dc:creator: @Rodgerwilco Rodgerwilco
item.description:
@Rodgerwilco wrote:

Install wifi and download your program online like a boss.

Read full topic

item.title: TI84 Programming - Exams
item.dc:creator: @ollie123 Ollie123
item.description:
@ollie123 wrote:

Before all of my exams we get told that “devices which contain an electronic storage facility” are prohibited. We’re not even allowed USB pen drives in our pockets or watches.

Read full topic

item.title: TI84 Programming - Exams
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote=“The Wanderer, post:9, topic:439960”][quote author=CodeForFame link=topic=542649.msg3977016#msg3977016 date=1334775035]

If you really want to sneak one by, you should be able to just archive the program to save it from being wiped. Though, it depends on how they’re clearing it.

I don’t need to save the program. I can easily reprogram it in like a minute. Like I said, I’m given all the formulas so there’s no use in saving it inside the calculator. There really is no difference in using a shortcut versus typing everything out.

@Fat Cookies, there’s nothing really difficult about anything. It’s just that the quadratic formula is a nice method of double checking my work. I’m not stupid and my intention is not cheating lol.
[/quote]If you can reprogram it, then why don’t you spend the time you would programming it by checking your work?

Reprogramming it and using it 10 times is probably faster than checking your work 10 times. I guess if you only had to do one problem it would take a little bit too much time to program it while taking the test.[/quote]Not at all… Taking the given and plugging in the answer takes almost no time.

Writing the program, and then making sure it works properly will easily take longer.

You should also remember that he’s only doing basic algebra; it’s not like he’s doing something that computers can do better than humans, except basic arithmetic, which will still be done on the calculator.

Read full topic

item.title: TI84 Programming - Exams
item.dc:creator: @the_wanderer The Wanderer
item.description:
@the_wanderer wrote:

[quote=“CodeForFame, post:7, topic:439960”][quote author=whackatre link=topic=542649.msg3976925#msg3976925 date=1334765712]

If you really want to sneak one by, you should be able to just archive the program to save it from being wiped. Though, it depends on how they’re clearing it.

I don’t need to save the program. I can easily reprogram it in like a minute. Like I said, I’m given all the formulas so there’s no use in saving it inside the calculator. There really is no difference in using a shortcut versus typing everything out.

@Fat Cookies, there’s nothing really difficult about anything. It’s just that the quadratic formula is a nice method of double checking my work. I’m not stupid and my intention is not cheating lol.
[/quote]If you can reprogram it, then why don’t you spend the time you would programming it by checking your work?[/quote]
Reprogramming it and using it 10 times is probably faster than checking your work 10 times. I guess if you only had to do one problem it would take a little bit too much time to program it while taking the test.

Read full topic

If you know how to reprogram it during the test, you obviously know how to do the work, and most require you show that work, so just do it…

item.title: TI84 Programming - Exams
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

Well I don’t know anything about the American school system but in tea-drinking country they say: “Your graphical calculators will be reset as you enter the exam”, but in reality it never happens. The thing is, there’s no point whatsoever because you are expected to show all your working on the exam anyway to gain marks, so if you “cheat”, you’re just cheating yourself out of the marks which is just plain retarded.

What are you even finding so difficult that requires you to use a program anyway. The only actual “special” functions I use on my calculator is sketching graphs and recursion/iterative things. Mainly its just basic functions and operators stuck together.

Read full topic

item.title: TI84 Programming - Exams
item.dc:creator: @sp11k3t3ht3rd sp11k3t3ht3rd
item.description:
@sp11k3t3ht3rd wrote:

I almost got suspended for it. No joke. I don’t know how that would have gone over with the principal because there is no real policy against it, but just be careful and keep them to yourself if you’re gonna do it.

Read full topic

I showed my friend a few simple programs and then he was like. CHEATER GTFO.
